item.title: Blinken Says U.S. Aid to Niger in Jeopardy Following Coup
item.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken said American assistance to Niger is in jeopardy following a military coup.

item.title: The Bank of Japan made an important change to its monetary policy, signaling that it would tolerate higher yields on longer-term Japanese government bonds.
item.description: The Bank of Japan made an important change to its monetary policy, signaling that it would tolerate higher yields on longer-term Japanese government bonds.

item.title: Biogen will pay $7.3 billion to acquire Reata Pharmaceuticals, the owner of a rare-disease treatment with the potential to be a blockbuster.
item.description: Biogen will pay $7.3 billion to acquire Reata Pharmaceuticals, the owner of a rare-disease treatment with the potential to be a blockbuster.

item.title: The head of Niger's presidential guard declared himself the leader of a new junta after deposing a president who was a key U.S. ally in the fight against extremism.
item.description: The head of Niger’s presidential guard declared himself the leader of a new junta after deposing a president who was a key U.S. ally in the fight against extremism.

item.title: Exxon and Chevron collectively banked nearly $14 billion in second-quarter profits, down from last year's record-breaking levels but adding to their war chests.
item.description: Exxon and Chevron collectively banked nearly $14 billion in second-quarter profits, down from last year’s record-breaking levels but adding to their war chests.

item.title: A bankruptcy judge in New Jersey threw out the second chapter 11 case that Johnson & Johnson filed to resolve its mass talc liabilities.
item.description: A bankruptcy judge in New Jersey threw out the second chapter 11 case that Johnson & Johnson filed to resolve its mass talc liabilities.

item.title: Pay and price pressures showed fresh signs of retreating from the economy, adding to evidence that inflation is moving closer to the Federal Reserve's goal.
item.description: Pay and price pressures showed fresh signs of retreating from the economy, adding to evidence that inflation is moving closer to the Federal Reserve’s goal.

item.title: Federal regulators are proposing stricter fuel-economy standards for light-duty cars and trucks, saying the rules would save consumers money and reduce pollution.
item.description: Federal regulators are proposing stricter fuel-economy standards for light-duty cars and trucks, saying the rules would save consumers money and reduce pollution.

item.title: An exodus of executives from Goldman Sachs's asset-management division threatens to undermine a central pillar of CEO David Solomon's strategy for the Wall Street giant.
item.description: An exodus of executives from Goldman Sachs’s asset-management division threatens to undermine a central pillar of CEO David Solomon’s strategy for the Wall Street giant.

item.title: U.S. stocks rebounded Friday, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow rising 1%, 1.9%, and 0.5%, respectively. All three major indexes ended with weekly gains.
item.description: U.S. stocks rebounded Friday, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow rising 1%, 1.9%, and 0.5%, respectively. All three major indexes ended with weekly gains.

item.title: Facebook removed content related to Covid-19 in response to pressure from the Biden administration, including posts claiming the virus was man-made, according to internal company communications viewed by The Wall Street Journal.
item.description: Facebook removed content related to Covid-19 in response to pressure from the Biden administration, including posts claiming the virus was man-made, according to internal company communications viewed by The Wall Street Journal.

item.title: Putin pledged to ship food and provide more security assistance to a swath of African nations after his move to end a deal safeguarding the export of Ukrainian grain.
item.description: Putin pledged to ship food and provide more security assistance to a swath of African nations after his move to end a deal safeguarding the export of Ukrainian grain.

item.title: Russia's decision to pull out of the Ukraine grain deal is a high-stakes gamble that risks diplomatic tensions with China and Turkey.
item.description: Russia’s decision to pull out of the Ukraine grain deal is a high-stakes gamble that risks diplomatic tensions with China and Turkey.

item.title: Melinda French Gates has decided to continue as co-chair of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, working alongside her now ex-husband Bill Gates to manage the philanthropy.
item.description: Melinda French Gates has decided to continue as co-chair of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, working alongside her now ex-husband Bill Gates to manage the philanthropy.

item.title: The Kremlin is attempting one of the most complex corporate takeovers in history, seeking to seize control of the Wagner paramilitary group's global empire.
item.description: The Kremlin is attempting one of the most complex corporate takeovers in history, seeking to seize control of the Wagner paramilitary group’s global empire.

item.title: What's News: World-Wide
item.description: What’s News: World-Wide

item.title: What's News: Business & Finance
item.description: What’s News: Business & Finance

item.title: How the U.S. Economy Is Sticking the Soft Landing
item.description: Companies that are pulling back are also choosing to hold onto workers, avoiding the large-scale job cuts that led to recessions in earlier economic slowdowns.

item.title: That Cool New Bookstore? It's a Barnes & Noble.
item.description: Barnes & Noble used to be the book industry’s villain. Its new CEO wants to make it more like a scrappy indie outpost—596 of them, to be exact.

item.title: Troubles at Barclays Prompt a Shake-Up---and Banker Exits
item.description: Fifteen years after its fire-sale purchase of Lehman Brothers’ core assets jump-started its investment-banking business, the British lender is still trying to find its footing.
